title: PyTorch RNN Tutorials don't work on Windows
body_html:
The tutorials Classifying Names with a Character-Level RNN and Generating Names with a Character-Level RNN don't work on Windows.

They attempt to extract the category from the filename using

category = filename.split('/')[-1].split('.')[0]

which works on Linux where these look like 'data/names/Arabic.txt' but not on Windows where they look like 'data/names\\Arabic.txt'.

I suggest changing the code to

category = os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(filename))[0]
body_text:
The tutorials Classifying Names with a Character-Level RNN and Generating Names with a Character-Level RNN don't work on Windows.
They attempt to extract the category from the filename using
category = filename.split('/')[-1].split('.')[0]

which works on Linux where these look like 'data/names/Arabic.txt' but not on Windows where they look like 'data/names\\Arabic.txt'.
I suggest changing the code to
category = os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(filename))[0]
body:
The tutorials [Classifying Names with a Character-Level RNN](http://pytorch.org/tutorials/intermediate/char_rnn_classification_tutorial.html) and [Generating Names with a Character-Level RNN](http://pytorch.org/tutorials/intermediate/char_rnn_generation_tutorial.html) don't work on Windows.

They attempt to extract the category from the filename using

    category = filename.split('/')[-1].split('.')[0]

which works on Linux where these look like `'data/names/Arabic.txt'` but not on Windows where they look like `'data/names\\Arabic.txt'`.

I suggest changing the code to

    category = os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(filename))[0]
